description: {"blocks":[{"key":"60kv0","text":"The transition from the evaluation of a single time point to the examination of the entire dynamic evolution of a system is possible only in the presence of the proper framework. The strong variability of dynamic evolution makes the definition of an explanatory procedure for data fitting and data clustering challenging.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"89vlb","text":"Here we present CONNECTOR, a data-driven framework able to analyze and inspect longitudinal data in a straightforward and revealing way. When used to analyze tumor growth kinetics over time in 1599 patient-derived xenograft (PDX) growth curves from ovarian and colorectal cancers, CONNECTOR allowed the aggregation of time-series data through an unsupervised approach in informative clusters. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"841lu","text":"Through the lens of a new perspective of mechanism interpretation, CONNECTOR shed light onto novel model aggregations and identified unanticipated molecular associations with response to clinically approved therapies.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}
keywords: Longitudinal data, functional data analysis, clustering

{"blocks":[{"key":"72a8f","text":"To illustrate how CONNECTOR works we use patient-derived xenografts (PDXs) lines from 21 models generated from chemotherapy-naive high-grade serous epithelial ovarian cancer.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":18,"length":10}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"4vo8s","text":"Introduction","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":12}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"f89p1","text":"The transition from the evaluation of a single time point to the examination of the entire dynamic evolution of a system is possible only in the presence of the proper framework. ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"73eoi","text":"Here we introduce CONNECTOR, a data-driven framework able to analyze and inspect longitudinal high-dimensional data in a straightforward and revealing way. CONNECTOR is a tool for the unsupervised analysis of longitudinal data, that is, it can process any sample consisting of measurements collected sequentially over time. CONNECTOR is built on the model-based approach for clustering functional data presented in","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":18,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":156,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"j9cn","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"8c3ha","text":"Let us note that this approach is particularly effective when observations are sparse and irregularly spaced, as growth curves usually are.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6c0k9","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"36lq3","text":"The CONNECTOR framework is based on the following steps:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":4,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1li5g","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"9u3f","text":"(1) The pre-processing step consists of a visualization of the longitudinal data by a line plot and a time grid heat map helping in the inspection of the sparsity of the time points.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":8,"length":19}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"11skn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"dhb57","text":"(2) Then, by means of the FDA analysis, the sampled curves are processed by CONNECTOR with a functional clustering algorithm based on a mixed effect model. This step requires a model selection phase, in which the dimension of the spline basis vector measures and number of clusters are computed that help the user to properly set the two free parameters of the model. The selection of the optimal set of parameter is supported by the generation of several plots.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":76,"length":9},{"style":"bold","offset":177,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8gdp5","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1a66t","text":"(3) Once the model selection phase is completed, the output of CONNECTOR is composed of several graphical visualizations to easily mine the results.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":3},{"style":"bold","offset":53,"length":6},{"style":"bold","offset":63,"length":9}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{"0":{"type":"citation","mutability":"IMMUTABLE","data":{"authors":"James, Gareth M and Sugar, Catherine A","can_edit":1,"date":null,"doi":"https://doi.org/10.1198/016214503000189","guid":"C0F9AB90141511ED93E2BB784AB26DFB","id":1902,"journal":"Journal of the American Statistical Association","protocol_id":null,"title":"Clustering for sparsely sampled functional data"}}}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"5tl84","text":"Model Selection Tools","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"8nemp","text":"Before running the fitting and clustering approach, we have to properly chose the two free parameters:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"1jps7","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6cipp","text":"the spline basis dimension, p ;\n","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":28,"length":2}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"aape8","text":"the number of clusters, G.\n","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":24,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"37u3b","text":"We developed several functions to enable the user to properly set these free parameters.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}}],"entityMap":{}}

{"blocks":[{"key":"ba1j1","text":"The spline basis dimension - p","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"bold","offset":0,"length":30}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"c6qcn","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"fl1p7","text":"The dimension of the spline basis can be chose by exploiting the BasisDimension.Choice function, by taking the","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":65,"length":21}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"7c3nv","text":"p ∈ [pmin , pmax] value corresponding to the largest cross-validated likelihood, as proposed in ","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":0,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":5,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":12,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":6,"length":4},{"style":"sub","offset":13,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"afsl3","text":" ","type":"atomic","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[{"key":0,"offset":0,"length":1}],"data":{}},{"key":"fchhu","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4o40m","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"167u5","text":"Where the interval of values [pmin , pmax] is given by the user. In particular, a ten-fold cross-validation approach is implemented: firstly the data are split into 10 equal-sized parts, secondly the model is fitted considering 9 parts and the computation of the log-likelihood on the excluded part is performed.","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":30,"length":5},{"style":"italic","offset":37,"length":1},{"style":"sub","offset":31,"length":4},{"style":"sub","offset":38,"length":3}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"6be5n","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"78p8o","text":"In details two plots are returned:","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4q2c1","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"a4ock","text":"The $CrossLogLikePlot return the plot of the mean tested log-likelihoods versus the dimension of the basis, see Figure 4. Each gray dashed line corresponds to the cross-log-likelihood values obtained on different test/learning sets and the solid black line is their mean value. The resulting plot could be used as a guide to choose the largest cross-validated likelihood. Specifically, the optimal value of p is generally the smallest ensuring the larger values of the mean cross-log-likelihood function.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":4,"length":17},{"style":"italic","offset":407,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"drsra","text":"The $KnotsPlot shows the time series curves (top) together with the knots distribution over the time grid (bottom), see Figure 5. The knots divide the time domain into contiguous intervals, and the curves are fitted with separate polynomials in each interval. Hence, this plot allows the user to visualize whether the knots properly split the time domain considering the distribution of the sampled observations. The user should choose p such that the number of cubic polynomials (i.e., p − 1) defined in each interval is able to follow the curves dynamics.","type":"ordered-list-item","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[{"style":"italic","offset":4,"length":10},{"style":"italic","offset":436,"length":1},{"style":"italic","offset":487,"length":1}],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"b2rv3","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"3vksm","text":"","type":"unstyled","depth":0,"inlineStyleRanges":[],"entityRanges":[],"data":{}},{"key":"4sash","text":"#
